author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: How Maddrey Became the N.Y.P.D.’s Top Officer Despite Years of Scandal
description: Jeffrey Maddrey, the former chief of department, built ties when he walked beats in Brooklyn. That seemed to insulate him as lawsuits and serious accusations against him piled up.
content: Over the years, Jeffrey B. Maddrey toiled as a beat cop in half a dozen Brooklyn precincts. He nurtured hundreds of officers he oversaw as an inspector. He quelled violent crime in a dangerous part of Brownsville.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 581
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Jan. 12, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Israel’s Campaign in Syrian Border Area Prompts Fears It Plans to Stay
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s order for Israeli troops to “take over” a buffer zone with Syria upended decades of relative calm along the de facto border between the two countries.
content: Israeli soldiers have raided Syrian border villages, prompting nervous residents to huddle in their homes. They have captured the country’s highest peak, have set up roadblocks between Syrian towns and now overlook local villages from former Syrian military outposts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: The Last House Standing
description: For people whose homes are spared in a wildfire while their neighbors lose everything, the road ahead can be isolating, plagued by feelings of guilt and shame.
content: After evacuating her home early Wednesday morning and escaping the fires that had engulfed swaths of Altadena, Calif., Monica Perez clutched her rosary and chanted a Hail Mary as her 19-year-old son drove the two of them up the I-5.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Columbia Professor Says She Was Pushed to Retire Because of Her Activism
description: Katherine Franke, a law professor and vocal advocate of pro-Palestinian students, had been under investigation over remarks she made about Israeli students.
content: Columbia University and one of its longtime law professors, Katherine Franke, have severed ties after an investigation stemming from her advocacy on behalf of pro-Palestinian students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Why Singapore’s First Family Is Locked in a Bitter Feud Over a House
description: A son of the country’s founding father says he has been persecuted by the government because of a feud with his older brother, who until May was prime minister.
content: The bungalow was built for a Dutch trader in colonial times, but it has become part of modern Singaporean lore. It was where Lee Kuan Yew lived for decades, where he started his political party and where he began building Singapore into one of the richest countries in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: New York to Cut 10,000 Migrant Beds but Open New Shelter in the Bronx
description: The Hall Street shelter in Brooklyn, which drew numerous complaints, is among several that will soon close in New York.
content: New York City officials plan to eliminate 10,000 beds for migrants, including closing one of the largest shelters in Brooklyn that had housed up to 4,000 people and drew quality-of-life and crime complaints from the nearby residential neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: O Canada, Come Join Us
description: Perhaps Trump is not making a threat but offering an opportunity.
content: My great-great-grandmother was born in Saint John, New Brunswick, and first saw the United States as a 10-year-old. My great-grandfather was an Irish Canadian who married a Maine girl. My wife’s father was born in Ontario, descended from a long line of Newfoundlanders, and a print of skaters on Ottawa’s Rideau Canal decorates our pantry even now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales and Christopher Lee
title: Meet the Latino Boys Decked Out for Their Version of the Quinceañera
description: In America, boys looking to celebrate their entry into adulthood are having their own, often lavish, quinceañero parties — a new take on a centuries-old tradition reserved only for girls.
content: On a Saturday last fall, a Mexican American teenager in Corpus Christi, Texas, had everything planned out for a coming-of-age party. It would have custom-made jewelry, a string quartet to play renditions of pop songs and a group of high school freshmen in black tailcoat tuxedos to perform a dance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: He’s the N.F.L. Player. She Gets the Autograph Requests.
description: By documenting the up-and-down lifestyle of a professional athlete’s wife, Allison Kucharczyk has surpassed the fame of her journeyman husband.
content: As he waited for a call from his agent in September, Isaac Rochell, a professional football player looking for a team, watched the National Football League’s opening weekend games on television with his infant daughter. His wife needed a baby sitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
title: Jack Smith, Who Led Prosecutions of Trump, Resigns
description: Mr. Smith, a special counsel appointed by Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, had signaled that he would step down before Donald J. Trump’s inauguration.
content: Jack Smith, the special counsel who brought two failed federal prosecutions against President-elect Donald J. Trump, resigned this week, according to a footnote buried in court papers — a remarkably muted conclusion to a fight that redefined the nation’s legal and political landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Morris
title: Sam Moore of the Dynamic Soul Duo Sam & Dave Is Dead at 89
description: Mr. Moore and Dave Prater stormed the R&B and pop charts with indelible hits like “Soul Man” and “Hold On, I’m Comin’.”
content: Sam Moore, the tenor half of the scorching soul duo Sam & Dave — known for indelible hits like “Soul Man,” “Hold On, I’m Comin’” and “I Thank You” — died on Friday in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Five Presidents and a Funeral
description: The pious Carter and profane Trump had some things in common.
content: Jimmy Carter was exactly where he wanted to be at his funeral on Thursday — at a deliberate remove from his fellow presidents. And slightly above them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Women Really Want to Talk After Seeing ‘Babygirl’
description: Audiences may not be able to agree on how erotic the director Halina Reijn’s erotic thriller is, but it’s starting rich conversations.
content: In reviews, in theaters and in group texts pinging across the country, “Babygirl,” the erotic thriller starring Nicole Kidman, has proved somewhat divisive. Who has the power, Romy, the high-powered tech executive played by Ms. Kidman, or the 20-something intern, to whom she willingly submits? Are certain moments supposed to be sexy or funny? Is Romy’s kink — which involves being told what to do — even that kinky?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: For Just Dollars a Day, Inmates Fight California’s Fires
description: Hundreds of incarcerated people are firefighting in Los Angeles. They are paid a maximum of $10.24 a day, and receive an additional $1 for each hour that they battle the deadly blazes.
content: More than 900 prisoners are battling the deadly flames ripping through the Los Angeles area. Their presence provides much-needed manpower to depleted fire crews but has also revived criticism of the practice, including over their low pay for dangerous work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Stephanie Hsu Loves a Cold Plunge Any Time
description: “Even if it’s January,” the star of the new TV series “Laid” said, “I will find the fire in me to do it.”
content: Stephanie Hsu was waiting for the universe to give her a sign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: Tulsa Massacre Was a ‘Coordinated, Military-Style Attack,’ Federal Report Says
description: The Justice Department’s conclusion follows an investigation of the 1921 atrocity in Oklahoma in which up to 300 Black residents were killed.
content: The Tulsa Race Massacre of 1921, in which a prosperous Black neighborhood in Oklahoma was destroyed and up to 300 people were killed, was not committed by an uncontrolled mob but was the result of “a coordinated, military-style attack” by white citizens, the Justice Department said in a report released Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Palisades Fire Could Test Getty Center’s Efforts to Protect Its Art Collection
description: The museum, which describes itself as the “safest places for art during a fire,” is now in a mandatory evacuation zone. Officials said the galleries “are safe and protected.”
content: Angelenos woke up Saturday morning to find that the Getty Center, one of Los Angeles’s most renowned art museums, is now squarely in the mandatory evacuation zone as the Palisades fire’s footprint has grown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Republicans Can Slow but Not Stop Electric Vehicles, Experts Say
description: More car buyers are expected to eventually pick battery-powered cars and trucks as prices fall and technology improves, even if Biden-era incentives disappear.
content: To a large extent, the electric vehicle market in the United States runs on Democratic policies. There are federal tax credits for car buyers. Subsidies for battery manufacturing. Cheap loans to build electric car factories. Grants for chargers. Regulations that push automakers to sell more vehicles with no tailpipe emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Yasinski
title: Is a Heated Workout More Effective?
description: Here’s what happens to your body during a hot fitness class.
content: For some people, sweating through an intensely hot workout class can border on a spiritual experience. For others, a toasty studio simply offers some relief from frigid winter weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Zhu and Meredith Cohn
title: Regulators Tell Baltimore Drug Program to ‘Cease and Desist’
description: Maryland issued the order after an investigation by The New York Times and The Baltimore Banner traced overdoses and deaths to an addiction program offering free housing.
content: Maryland health regulators on Friday said they had ordered an addiction treatment provider to stop seeing patients after an investigation by The New York Times and The Baltimore Banner showed it had placed some of them in apartment buildings where drug use was rampant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: How Much Would Buying Greenland Cost?
description: President-elect Donald Trump wants to buy the territory from Denmark, which says it’s not for sale. DealBook asked experts how they’d approach the deal.
content: Donald Trump, who has long loved big real estate deals, has made it clear that he’s serious about striking one for Greenland. Never mind that Denmark, which controls the island, says the territory isn’t for sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Holmes
title: Is H.R. Really Your Friend?
description: Don’t count on human resources to take your side in a workplace issue, especially if it involves a conflict with your boss.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Don’t the Lives of Women and Girls Matter?
description: Trump is likely to slash funding for women’s health organizations in the name of “protecting life” — but the result will be death.
content: When he returns to the White House, President-elect Trump is widely expected to slash funding for women’s health organizations around the world, and people on the left and the right alike are focused on what that means for abortions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: What Dr. Ruth Left Behind — Archiving the Stuff of a Life
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 11, 2025.
content: “It was like ‘phone call with Oprah,’ ‘meeting with Kissinger,’ ‘go on Arsenio Hall.’ It was such a cross-section of pop culture.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Lisa Lerer
title: As L.A. Fires Rage, Trump and Newsom’s Hostilities Resurface
description: California’s Democratic governor, Gavin Newsom, and President-elect Donald J. Trump have long feuded. Can the rancor be set aside to help a devastated city recover?
content: As fires raged around Los Angeles, Gov. Gavin Newsom, Democrat of California, arrived at a Santa Monica fire station on Wednesday to meet with President Biden carrying a printout of his state’s request for a major disaster declaration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Not So Fast on That Peaceful Transfer of Power
description: We won’t know anything for real until the next Democrat wins.
content: The wave of self-congratulation that followed the certification of the 2024 presidential election on Monday was premature in the extreme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: It Was a Destination for Hat Lovers. Now It’s Ashes.
description: The Wellema Hat Company was one of many local Los Angeles businesses destroyed by this week’s fires. Now its founders are figuring out how to — or even if they can — start over.
content: It took nearly a decade for Cody Wellema to perfect his dream hat shop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Why Airlines Are Optimistic About 2025
description: The industry is enjoying a strong demand for tickets and rising profits, but it remains vulnerable to unexpected problems like a recession or a surge in inflation.
content: This year just got started, but it is already shaping up nicely for U.S. airlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nostrant
title: Newsom Wants to Know Why Fire Hydrants Went Dry
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California ordered an inquiry into a loss of water pressure after it was revealed that a reservoir was offline when the fires started.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California ordered an inquiry into the county’s water management after reports emerged that a critical reservoir was offline when the fires started and that firefighters were left with sputtering — and then dry — hydrants as they battled blazes ripping through Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,303
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Jan. 12, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: The Painting, the Photograph and the War for Ukraine’s Culture
description: An image depicting a famous 19th-century painting of Cossacks, with current Ukrainian soldiers standing in for the warriors, has struck a chord as Kyiv battles to assert its identity.
content: It looks like a serene snapshot from Ukraine’s battlefield: A group of armor-clad soldiers huddled around a makeshift table scattered with food and playing cards. Some laugh or smoke, and one lounges on the ground, smiling as he scrolls through his phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Charles Person, Youngest of the Original Freedom Riders, Dies at 82
description: In 1961, he and 12 other civil rights activists were nearly killed for trying to integrate interstate bus terminals across the South.
content: Charles Person, the youngest of the 13 original Freedom Riders who traveled from Washington to Birmingham, Ala., in 1961 in an effort to integrate interstate bus terminals across the South — and who were nearly beaten to death for doing so — died on Wednesday at his home in Fayetteville, Ga. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Jeju Air Flight Recorder Stopped Working 4 Minutes Before Plane Crash
description: The missing data deepens the puzzle of what caused the deadly air disaster in Muan, South Korea, late last month.
content: The flight recorder of the Jeju Air passenger jet that crashed last month, killing ​179 people, stopped recording for​ its last four minutes, South Korean officials said on Saturday, a significant setback for investigators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Hear New Affordable Care Act Case on Preventative Care
description: Lower courts ruled that a task force that determines which treatments must be covered at no cost had not been validly appointed.
content: The Supreme Court said on Friday that it would take up a challenge to a part of the Affordable Care Act that requires insurance companies to cover some kinds of preventative care at no cost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Top Senators on Armed Services Panel Briefed on F.B.I. Probe of Hegseth
description: The committee’s Republican chairman and its top Democrat were briefed on F.B.I. findings into Pete Hegseth, Donald Trump’s defense secretary pick. Democrats questioned whether there were gaps.
content: The top members of the Senate Armed Services Committee were briefed late Friday afternoon on the findings from the F.B.I.’s background check of Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to serve as defense secretary, according to two people aware of the briefings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Sudan’s Military Recaptures Key City From Paramilitary Accused of Genocide
description: Celebrations erupted in military-controlled areas, stoking hopes the victory might be a turning point in Sudan’s ruinous civil war.
content: The Sudanese military recaptured a key city in Sudan’s breadbasket region on Saturday, chasing out a paramilitary group that the United States accused last week of genocide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Reading Aloud
description: Reading alone is a deeply enjoyable activity. But being read to has its own irreplaceable allure.
content: The Harvard Sentences are hundreds of sentences that have been used for many decades to test technologies in which understanding speech is essential, like telephone systems and hearing aids. I came across the list recently and was charmed by it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: The Very Long Wait for Jeff Bezos’ Big Rocket Is Coming to an End
description: If New Glenn lifts off on Monday as planned, the Amazon founder’s rocket company will be on track to give Elon Musk’s SpaceX some genuine competition.
content: The foundational building block for Jeff Bezos’ space dreams is finally ready to launch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: Cynthia Erivo Made a Promise to See Her Characters Through
description: Whether it’s Elphaba in “Wicked” or Celie in “The Color Purple,” the star doesn’t choose parts “frivolously”; she wants roles that stay with viewers.
content: Elphaba might have been reluctant to go to Shiz University, but Cynthia Erivo still wants to get a Ph.D.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Far From the Fires, the Deadly Risks of Smoke Are Intensifying
description: Researchers see a growing health danger from the vast plumes of pollution spawned by wildfires like the ones devastating Los Angeles.
content: It kills more people each year than car crashes, war or drugs do. This invisible killer is the air pollution from sources like cars and trucks or factory smokestacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Getting the Art Out of the Studio and Onto Your Kicks
description: Sky Gellatly is a matchmaker between artists and brands, and his eye for deals has resulted in some flashy, and lucrative, collaborations.
content: In the robustly expanding realm of artist-brand collaborations, Sky Gellatly, at 44, has operated as a best-kept secret. Style and art world insiders may credit him as a canny go-between for artists and fashion brands keen to exploit potentially lucrative partnerships. But he has, up to now, stayed mostly under the radar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Los Angeles Is Starring in an All-Too-Real Disaster Story
description: A reporter, an L.A. native, has watched movies and TV destroy her hometown for years, but nothing can prepare someone for seeing real devastation.
content: I grew up in Los Angeles, first in a canyon enclave minutes from the beach, then on a wide street in the Pacific Palisades. This means that I have spent my life watching my hometown destroyed onscreen. In films and series, Los Angeles has endured meteor strikes, alien invasions, fires, floods, zombies, volcanoes, seismic catastrophe, multiple Sharknados. To live in Los Angeles as a moviegoer or a TV watcher is to see Hollywood delight in its ruin. Often I shared that delight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: J. Fraser Stoddart, Who Developed Microscopic Machines, Dies at 82
description: He grew up playing with model construction sets. As an adult, he tinkered with molecules instead, creating nanomachines and winning a Nobel Prize.
content: J. Fraser Stoddart, a Scottish-born scientist who went from playing with construction sets as a boy to building molecular machines a thousand times smaller than the width of a human hair, known as nanomachines, for which he shared the 2016 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, died on Dec. 30 in Melbourne, Australia. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: L.A. Mayor and Fire Chief Try to Show a United Front Amid Tensions
description: At a news conference, Mayor Karen Bass said she and the fire chief, who claimed the city had not sufficiently funded the Fire Department, were in “lock step.”
content: Mayor Karen Bass of Los Angeles tried to project a unified front with her fire chief amid obvious tension on Saturday, a day after the chief criticized city officials and said they had failed to adequately fund her department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Palisades Fire Threatens Brentwood, Including the Getty Center
description: The authorities expanded mandatory evacuation orders to parts of the neighborhood on Friday night as the biggest blaze in the Los Angeles area grew rapidly.
content: The Palisades fire in Los Angeles lurched east late Friday night, prompting emergency officials to expand mandatory evacuation orders to Brentwood, including the Getty Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: In Congress, a Push for Proxy Voting for New Parents Draws Bipartisan Support
description: A group of younger lawmakers is pressing to change House rules to allow members who are new parents to vote remotely.
content: Representative Brittany Pettersen, a second-term Colorado Democrat, was not planning to have a second child at the age of 43.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Democracy is Not Facing a Global Extinction Event
description: Right-wing parties may be in the ascendant, but overall, democracy is not at risk.
content: Democracy, it is often heard these days, is in crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: New Yorkers Have Little Data but Big Feelings About Congestion Pricing
description: Manhattan commuters are already marveling at what appears to be less traffic — and grousing about the new $9 tolls.
content: It’s too soon to know whether New York City’s new congestion pricing plan has succeeded in reducing traffic in Manhattan. And it will be a while before we know if the new fees will raise the billions of dollars proponents have promised. But even before the hard data arrives, New Yorkers (and those who commute to New York) have had a lot to say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How a Driving Instructor to the Stars Spends Her Sundays
description: Shanti Gooljar grabs some coffee before eight hours of heart-racing driving lessons around New York City. She caps off her day by having dinner with her son.
content: Shanti Gooljar recently got a $2,000 tip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: As a Felon, Trump Upends How Americans View the Presidency
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has worked for years to discredit any and all criminal and civil cases against him as nothing more than politically motivated witch hunts.
content: A big economic package, mass deportations, maybe even some invasions of other countries. Oh, and one more item. “I’ll do my little thing tomorrow,” a busy President-elect Donald J. Trump mentioned the other night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Ben Stiller on ‘Severance,’ Selling Out and Being Jewish Today
description: The actor-director discusses the long-awaited return of the hit series, the comedies that made him a star and growing up with his famous parents.
content: When the Emmy-award winning series “Severance” (Apple TV+) makes its return on Jan. 17, it will resume the story of, and maybe provide some answers to, the mysterious doings of Lumon Industries. In case you haven’t seen the show or are in need of a refresher — it has been three long years since the first season aired — Lumon is the creepily enigmatic corporation staffed by office drones, including the protagonist Mark (played by Adam Scott), who have willingly chosen to have their consciousnesses artificially split in two. That is, the employees’ work selves (known as innies) and their off-hours selves (their outies) have been literally psychologically disconnected — to disorientating and disturbing effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: What Will Congestion Pricing Do to Manhattan Dining?
description: Days into the new charges, some restaurant owners say suppliers are raising prices. Others are giving customer discounts, and many fear the fallout for workers.
content: The sky did not fall during the first week of Manhattan’s congestion pricing. But you wouldn’t have known that by talking to restaurant owners in the affected zone, who are in a state of high anxiety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: 3 New Thrillers Fueled by Obsession and Blackmail
description: Our columnist on the month’s most exciting releases.
content: Obsession, romantic and otherwise, is the dominant theme of this month’s thrillers, whose characters often live on the edge of madness. Let’s start with Feeney’s BEAUTIFUL UGLY (Flatiron, 295 pp., $28.99). Feeney is known for pulling jaw-dropping surprises on her readers, and in her latest novel lulls us into believing that we’re reading a straightforward missing-person mystery. Abby Goldman, an investigative journalist in England, is driving home and talking to her husband, a novelist named Grady Green, when she stops to help a woman lying in the road. She never returns, and though her car turns up, she’s not in it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Lebanon’s Prime Minister Meets With Syrian Leader
description: The visit by Prime Minister Najib Mikati was the first official trip by the Lebanese leader to meet with the new government of Syria.
content: In his first official visit to Syria to meet with the new government there, the Lebanese prime minister on Saturday called for a way for the two countries to enable masses of Syrian refugees in Lebanon to head home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Despite Trump’s Attacks, Republicans Made Big Gains in Mail Voting
description: As Republican voters embraced a practice that Donald J. Trump railed against for years, softening his tone only slightly in 2024, the party eroded a key Democratic advantage across the country.
content: Republicans made almost universal gains in mail voting during the 2024 election, eroding a key Democratic advantage in nearly every state that tracks party registration, according to a data analysis by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meghan McCarron
title: In One of L.A.’s Richest ZIP Codes, Food Service Workers Also Lost Their Homes
description: In addition to pricey mansions, the homes of working-class people were also lost, including a mobile home park on Pacific Coast Highway.
content: Before Summer Marshall headed to her bakery job on Tuesday, she dropped off her daughter at school and picked up a few supplies from Trader Joe’s in case the Santa Ana winds knocked out power. She was headed back to the mobile home she shared with her mother in Pacific Palisades when she saw a huge plume of smoke over the Santa Monica mountains.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should Students’ Efforts Be Rewarded With Good Grades?
description: Readers respond to a guest essay that argued that high grades should be strictly for excellence.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Scott Bessent, Trump’s Billionaire Treasury Pick, Will Shed Assets to Avoid Conflicts
description: Financial disclosure forms show hundreds of millions of assets including property in the Bahamas and investments in Bitcoin and bets against China’s currency.
content: Scott Bessent, the billionaire hedge fund manager whom President-elect Donald J. Trump picked to be his Treasury secretary, plans to divest from dozens of funds, trusts and investments in preparation to become the nation’s top economic policymaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Seymour P. Lachman, Who Exposed Political Cabals in Albany, Dies at 91
description: In “Three Men in a Room,” Mr. Lachman, an educator and former state senator, charted how power was secretly and corruptly wielded in New York State government.
content: Seymour P. Lachman, a former New York State senator who was so fed up with the political shenanigans in Albany that he quit the Legislature and wrote two books that helped spur reforms, died on Jan. 2 at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Calls Meta’s Ending of Fact-Checking Program ‘Shameful’
description: Responding to a question from a reporter, the president said he believed Americans “want to tell the truth.”
content: President Biden criticized Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, on Friday for deciding to abandon its fact-checking program on Facebook and Instagram, calling it a “shameful” decision that undermines America’s commitment to telling the truth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: My Co-op Is Overcharging Me, Possibly on Purpose. What Can I Do?
description: Proving that a co-op board is acting in bad faith can be difficult.
content: Q: I believe I am facing retaliation from the board of my Manhattan co-op. In 2018, the building manager was supposed to correct an error with my account, but she never removed the baseless late charges, and has since added more. Management has used some of my maintenance payments to pay these late charges, rather than applying them to my monthly costs. I ran for a co-op board seat, but within days got “notices to cure” all the way to “eviction,” based on these erroneous charges. The board did not file their papers correctly the first time, but they have filed them again in housing court. What do I do next?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: This Roasted Cauliflower Dish Is Positively Zingy
description: There’s no other way to accurately describe the incredibly bright nước chấm-like sauce that dresses the burnished slices.
content: My wonderful colleague Allison Jiang — you may remember her from this excellent dive into Lunar New Year hot pot parties — has assembled a collection of 14 easy, healthy dinner recipes to cook on repeat. “Healthy can look like different things to different people,” Allison writes, “but the goal with these dishes is to help you get cooking, and to make something that feels nourishing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: In San Francisco, Controversial Flags Have Had Their Ups and Downs
description: A collection of historic flags, some with provocative associations, was removed from the plaza outside City Hall for Mayor Daniel Lurie’s inauguration. By Friday, they were flying again.
content: The inauguration of Mayor Daniel Lurie of San Francisco on Wednesday in the plaza outside City Hall had it all: prominent speakers, a packed audience, and performers ranging from Chinese lion dancers to the Gay Men’s Chorus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz and Hannah Yoon
title: How Sleepy Bucks County Became a Rival to the Hamptons
description: First came the Hadids. Then Bradley Cooper. Now, with luxury inns going up, the area around New Hope, Pa. is taking a glamorous turn.
content: It’s hard to pinpoint when things began to change around here but you might start with the arrival of Yolanda Hadid in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Harry and Meghan Visit Survivors of Los Angeles Fires
description: The couple met with emergency medical workers and people who evacuated their homes in Pasadena, Calif., near the giant Eaton blaze.
content: Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, met with wildfire survivors and emergency medical workers on Friday in Pasadena, Calif., as they suggested ways for people to help victims of the deadly blazes in Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: I Think Knot
description: Jeffrey Martinovic’s Sunday puzzle enchants and entangles.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: One Taken for a Ride
description: Ryan McCarty’s tough Saturday grid spins us around.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Ryan McCarty’s 25th Saturday grid for The New York Times since his crossword debut in 2017. It features all his trademarks: musical references, off-kilter and very difficult cluing and a pinwheel pattern in the puzzle’s geometry. This last trait adds to the challenge, because it creates four chunky corners connected by only an entry or two; if you don’t know the answers, it’s easy to get stuck.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sex and Violence, but Make It Literary
description: Molly recommends Annie Ernaux’s photographic record of a love affair and a sociologist’s study of the moments when conflict turns violent.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller, Alexandra Berzon, Kellen Browning and Shawn Hubler
title: L.A. Was Prepared for Serious Fires. But It Wasn’t Ready for Four.
description: “There were too many houses to protect, and not enough engines,” one fire captain in Los Angeles said. Though fire officials say they were well-prepared and simply overwhelmed by the elements, questions are being raised about whether the intensity of modern fires requires a new playbook.
content: Follow continuing coverage of the wildfires in Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Trump vs. the Bureaucrats
description: MAGA has turned “the administrative state” into a battle cry.
content: As political red meat, “the deconstruction of the administrative state” sounds like a yawn — too academic, too abstract, too boring, too many syllables.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner and Ryan Mac
title: Amid L.A. Evacuations, Fears of Looting Take Hold
description: Residents barred from returning to their neighborhoods face a secondary threat, and the city, with painful collective memories of looting, is on guard.
content: A resident checking people’s identifications. Neighbors following a man because he is wearing a backpack. Rumors spreading of a trespasser caught stealing Emmys and Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: The Terrifying Realization That an Unresponsive Patient Is ‘Still in There’
description: After brain injury, some patients are no longer able to respond to the world around them. Is this really the case?
content: The fourth floor of the long-term-care hospital where I sometimes work houses patients with severe brain injuries. When I am called there to consult, I always hesitate before entering the room. Of all the ways that our bodies can fail, brain injuries are some of the most devastating to witness. Some patients moan involuntarily. Others lie still, their eyes open but unresponsive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Graff, Yan Zhuang and Shawn Hubler
title: Dry Vegetation Fuels L.A. Fires as Wind Speeds Drop
description: The largest of the blazes expanded east on Friday, even as wind speeds, which fueled the initial blaze, fell to normal levels.
content: The focus this week has been on how extreme winds have fueled the most destructive fires in Los Angeles’s history. But that’s not the only concern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Out in the Cold With Justin Trudeau
description: The prime minister’s celebrity helped bring him to power. Even after his popularity collapsed, it still drew crowds.
content: In light wool trousers, dress shoes and an overcoat that was partly open, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau was minimally clothed for the minus 13 degrees Celsius weather on Monday when he stepped out of his official residence to announce his resignation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Ukraine Says It Captured 2 North Korean Soldiers Fighting for Russia
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said the soldiers were captured in the western Kursk region, where Ukraine has been fighting to hold on to territory it seized last summer.
content: The Ukrainian authorities on Saturday announced the capture of two North Korean soldiers in Russia, saying they were the first to be taken alive since Pyongyang sent troops to assist Moscow’s war effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Once the Fires Are Out, California Must Remove Tons of Dangerous Debris
description: Clearing the toxic remnants of burned buildings around Los Angeles will require a complex and expensive mobilization. California has been there before.
content: When the flames in Los Angeles County are finally extinguished, the region will face the costly, time-consuming and heart-wrenching task of hauling away tons of toxic rubble. Given the scale of devastation in and around America’s second-largest city, that cleanup could become one of the country’s most complex debris removal efforts ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: You Don’t Get Disasters Like the Palisades Fire Without Human Failure
description: Can a city lose an entire neighborhood now and simply shuffle on, dragging the local memory like a ghost limb?
content: From the sky, it looked like a firebombing — nearly every structure in parts of Altadena burning at once and much of Pacific Palisades aflame overnight, a neighborhood of more than 20,000 leveled to its foundations and dusted with the ash of all that had stood before. Ash from homes and schools and churches, palm trees and chaparral, stuffed animals and onesies. More residue was suspended in the sky, where the sun rose Wednesday a spectacular blood orange, and through the alveoli of lungs throughout Los Angeles, where schools were closed by fear of toxic air. On the ground, what remained resembled ruins; the writer and environmentalist Bill McKibben compared the devastation to the catacombs of Pompeii.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKinnon de Kuyper
title: Pop-Up Donation Center Provides Relief for Displaced Angelenos
description: A community-ran donation center that started as two hot dog carts has grown into a full-scale relief effort for residents displaced by fires.
content: A community-ran donation center that started as two hot dog carts has grown into a full-scale relief effort for residents displaced by fires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, David Jouppi, Josh Finbow and Connor Nelson
title: How L.A. Firefighters Are Battling Deadly Wildfires
description: The most destructive wildfires in Los Angeles history are far from being contained. Kellen Browning, a New York Times reporter who spoke with firefighters on the front lines, describes what went wrong.
content: The most destructive wildfires in Los Angeles history are far from being contained. Kellen Browning, a New York Times reporter who spoke with firefighters on the front lines, describes what went wrong.
source.name: The New York Times
